Yep‚Äîyour bookmarklet ran, but this page blocks eval via CSP, so the alert never fired. Many big sites (including this one) forbid eval/Function so injected code can‚Äôt execute in-page. Quick fix: use a fallback that runs your code in a clean popup (no CSP), while still trying in-page first where allowed. How to use
On permissive sites: paste code ‚Üí Run (or Ctrl/Cmd+Enter) ‚Üí executes in-page.
On strict CSP sites (like this one): hit Run in Popup ‚Üí code runs in a clean about:blank window (alerts/modals work there).
If the popup is blocked, allow popups and try again.
Extras (optional)
Want ‚Äúrun in the original page‚Äù even with CSP? That‚Äôs not generally possible without a userscript manager/extension (Tampermonkey/Greasemonkey) or DevTools access; CSP is doing its job.
Want a version that always opens a separate full editor tab with local storage and a file loader/saver? Say the word and I‚Äôll drop a minimal one-file HTML you can keep offline.
If I "run in popup", will I still be able to access the dom?

Good question ‚Äî and important distinction.
If you hit Run in Popup in that bookmarklet, the code executes inside the popup‚Äôs own page (about:blank), not in the original page. That means:
‚úÖ It can run alert(), log things, etc.
‚ùå It cannot directly touch the DOM of the original page (because the popup is a separate origin/context).
So if your goal is DOM-poking (like document.querySelectorAll(...) on the current site), you really want the Run (in-page) button. That only fails on sites with Content Security Policy (CSP) blocking eval.
Options if you want DOM access but CSP blocks eval
Inline <script> injection
Instead of using eval, the bookmarklet can create a <script> tag with your code. CSP sometimes blocks inline scripts too, but often script injection from a bookmarklet slips by.
jsjavascript:(()=>{const s=document.createElement('script');s.textContent=prompt('JS?');document.body.appendChild(s);})();
This runs whatever you type in the prompt in the real page DOM.
Userscript extension (Tampermonkey/Greasemonkey)
Lets you bypass CSP restrictions and run code in-page. Ideal if you want ongoing hacks.
DevTools snippets
In Chrome/Firefox you can save ‚ÄúSnippets‚Äù of JS in DevTools ‚Üí Sources ‚Üí Snippets. They run in the page DOM and avoid bookmarklet CSP issues.
üëâ Do you want me to patch the bookmarklet so it falls back to injecting a <script> element instead of using eval when CSP blocks it? That way you still stay in the page DOM.

Is there a particular flavor of greasemonkey that should be preferred?
grease, tamper, violent ...

Short answer: use Tampermonkey for max compatibility, or Violentmonkey if you prefer open-source. Skip modern Greasemonkey unless you have a reason.
TL;DR picks
I want it to ‚Äújust work‚Äù everywhere (Chrome/Firefox/Edge/Brave): Tampermonkey
I want open-source with great compatibility: Violentmonkey
I only use Firefox and miss old scripts: not Greasemonkey‚Äîv4+ changed APIs and many scripts break
Why
Tampermonkey
Best script compatibility (most scripts are tested against it)
Rich features (per-site injection modes, CSP workarounds, good editor, backups, sync)
Violentmonkey
Open-source, lightweight, very compatible
Good editor, sync (Dropbox/Gist/etc), per-site controls
Greasemonkey (Firefox)
Post-v4 moved to async GM APIs and dropped/broke some legacy features; lots of older scripts don‚Äôt run without changes
For your use case (watch ChatGPT DOM, save JSON)
Either Tampermonkey or Violentmonkey on Firefox will be fine.
In settings, set injection to page (not content) if you need direct access to page globals.
If you later need to bypass stricter CSPs, Tampermonkey tends to have more knobs.

Change, and it applies immediately.

Not quite üëç ‚Äî this is where the scope trickiness comes in.
Inside the JS Pad userscript, there are two ‚Äúworlds‚Äù:
Pad internals (where function log(m){‚Ä¶} lives).
User code sandbox (where your snippets run).
When you type log("test") in the editor, you‚Äôre in the user code sandbox, which does not see the pad‚Äôs log function. That‚Äôs why nothing happens.
What does work right now
Running just 2+2 ‚Üí you should see 4 in the output pane.
Running alert("hi") ‚Üí will pop up a browser alert (unless the page blocks it).
How to make log() work in your snippets
We need to expose the pad‚Äôs logger into the user world.
Add this line right after the function log(m){‚Ä¶} in your script:
jswindow.jspadLog = (m) => log(m);
Now, in your code editor you can do:
jsjspadLog("test");
‚Ä¶and it will show up in the bottom output pane.
If you really want plain log("test") to work
You could also assign over the global log:
jswindow.log = (m) => log(m);
‚ö†Ô∏è But careful: some sites (and the browser console) may already use log, so overriding it could be confusing. Safer to use jspadLog.

What does the elipse at the start of that snippet mean?

Ah ‚Äî that ... at the start isn‚Äôt special JavaScript syntax by itself, it‚Äôs the spread operator.
Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs happening in that snippet:
js[...document.querySelectorAll('[data-message-author-role]')]
document.querySelectorAll(...) returns a NodeList, not a plain array.
A NodeList looks array-ish but doesn‚Äôt have methods like .map() or .filter().
[...] with the spread operator (...) takes that NodeList and spreads its items into a real array.
So:
Without it:
jsdocument.querySelectorAll('div')
// => NodeList(‚Ä¶) { 0: <div>‚Ä¶ }
With it:
js[...document.querySelectorAll('div')]
// => [ <div>‚Ä¶ , <div>‚Ä¶ ]
That way you can safely chain .map(...) right after.
‚úÖ Short form: [...] + ... = ‚Äúconvert NodeList into a real array.‚Äù

Good catch ‚Äî ‚ÄúCTA text‚Äù is jargon for Call-To-Action text.
On sites like ChatGPT, that can mean little extra UI snippets bundled into the DOM that aren‚Äôt really part of the conversation, e.g.:
Buttons like ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù, ‚ÄúRegenerate response‚Äù

If you‚Äôre building a clean messages[] array for the API, you usually want to strip those out, keeping only the actual text you typed and the model‚Äôs replies.
